encodingDesc.p: The characters are identified by IDREF pointing to information in the following declarations. Spain Ieronimo Horatio Ambassador Medina Castile Rogero Lorenzo Andrea Bellimperia Pedringano Lazarotto Isabel King of Portugal Alexandro Balthazar Alcario Messenger General Vollupo Don Pedro Captain Omnes Revenge Voice off Charon

langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by idREF which point to the following.

titlePage.titlePart: THE FIRST PART of Ieronimo. With the Wars of Portugall, and the life and death of Don Andra.

stage.p: Sound a Signate and passe ouer the stage. Enter at one dore The king of Spaine, Duke of Castile, Duke medina, Lorenzo, and Rogero: at another doore, Andrea, Horatio, and Ieronimo, Ieronimo kneeles downe, and the King creates him marshall of Spaine: Lorenzo putes on his spurres, and Andrea his sword, the king goes along with Ieronimo to his house, after a long Signate is sounded: Enter all the nobles, with couerd dishes to the banquet.
That done Enter all agen as before.

sp.speaker: Spai.
sp.l: Frolic Ieronimo, thou art now confirmed,
Marshall of Spaine, by all the dews
And customary rights unto thy office.

sp.speaker: Iero.
sp.l: My knee sings thanks unto your highness bounty,
Come hither boy Horatio, fold thy joints,
Kneel by thy fathers loins, and thank my liege,
by honouring me, thy Mother, and thyself,
with this high staff of office.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: O my liege I have a heart thrice stronger than my years,
and that shall answer gratefully for me.
Let not my youthful blush impair my valour,
If ever you have foes, or red field scars,
I will empty all my veins to serve your wars:
I will bleed for you: and more, what speech affords,
I will speak in drops when I do fail in words.

sp.speaker: Iero.
sp.l: Well spoke my boy, and on thy fathers side.
My liege how like you Don Horatios spirit,
what, doth it not promise fair,

sp.speaker: Spai.
sp.l: Aye and no doubt his merit will purchase more,
Knight Marshall rise, and still rise
Higher, and greater in thy Sovereigns eyes.

sp.speaker: Iero.
sp.l: O fortunate hour, blessed minute, happy day,
Able to ravish even my sense away,
Now I remember too: O sweet remembrance,
This day my years strike fifty, and in Rome,
They call the fifty year the year of Jubilee,
The merry year, the peaceful year, Jocund year,
A year of joy, of pleasure and delight,
This shall be my year of Jubilee, for it is my fifty.
Age ushers honour, it is no shame, confess:
Beard, thou art fifty full, not a hair less.

sp.speaker: Spai.
sp.l: How now, what news from spain, tribute returned.

sp.speaker: Embas.
sp.l: Tribute in words my liege, but not in coin.

sp.speaker: Spai.
sp.l: Ha: dare he still procrastinate with Spaine,
Not tribute paid, not three years payed,
It is not at his coin
But his slack homage, that we most repine.

sp.speaker: Iero.
sp.l: My liege, if my opinion might stand firm
Within your highness thoughts:

sp.speaker: Spai.
sp.l: Marshall, our kingdom calls thee father:
Therefore speak free
Thy counsel I will embrace, as I do thee.

sp.speaker: Iero.
sp.l: I thank your highness: then my Gracious liege,
I hold it meet by way of Embassage,
To demand his mind and the neglect of tribute:
But my liege here must be kind words,
Which doth oft besiege the ears of rough
Hewn tyrants more than blows.
O, a politic speech beguiles the ears of foes,
Marry my liege mistake me not I pray,
If friendly phrases, honeyed speech, bewitching accent,
Well-tuned melody, and all sweet gifts of nature,
Cannot avail or win him to it,
Then let him raise his gall up to his tongue,
And be as bitter as physicians drugs,
Stretch his mouth wider, with big swollen phrases:
O here is a Lad of mettle, stout Don Andrea,
Mettle to the crown
Would shake the kings hie court three handfuls down.

sp.speaker: Spai.
sp.l: And well picked out knight Marshall,
Speech well strung,
I had rather choose Horatio, were he not so young.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: I humbly thank your highness,
In placing me next unto his royal bosom.

sp.speaker: Spai.
sp.l: Now stand ye Lords to this election.

sp.speaker: Omnes
sp.l: Right pleasing our dread Sovereign,

sp.speaker: Medi.
sp.l: Only with pardon mighty Sovereign.

sp.speaker: Casti.
sp.l: I should have chose Don Lorenzo.
Aye Don Rogero,

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: O no, not me my Lords;
I am wars Champion, and my fees are swords,
Pray king, pray peers, let it be Don Andrea,
He is a worthy limb,
Loves wars and Soldiers therefore I love him.

sp.speaker: Iero.
sp.l: And I love him, and thee valiant Rogero,
Noble spirits, gallant bloods,
Your no wise insinuating Lords,
You have no tricks, you have none of all their flights.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: So, so, Andrea must be sent ambassador,
Lorenzo is not thought upon: good.
I will wake the Court, or startle out some blood.

sp.speaker: Spai.
sp.l: How stand you Lords to this election.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Right pleasing our dread Sovereign.

sp.speaker: Spai.
sp.l: then Don Andrea.

sp.speaker: Add.
sp.l: My approved liege.

sp.speaker: Spai.
sp.l: We make thee our Lord hie ambassador.

sp.speaker: and.
sp.l: Your highness circles me with honours bounds,
I still discharge the weight of your command,
with best respect, aye friendly tempered phrase,
Cannot affect the virtue of your charge,
I will be hard like thunder, and as rough,
as Northern tempests, or the vexed bowels,
Of too insulting waves, who at one blow,
Five merchant's wealths into the deep doth throw,
I will threaten crimson wars.

sp.speaker: Roge.
sp.l: Aye, Aye, that is good;
Let them keep coin, pay tribute with their blood.

sp.speaker: Spai.
sp.l: Farewell then don Andrea, to thy charge
Lords Let us in, joy shall be now our guest,
Let Us in to celebrate our second feast.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Andrea is gone ambassador,
Lorenza is not dreamt on in this age,
Hard fate,
when villains sit not in the highest state
Ambitions plumes that flourished in our court,
Severe authority has dashed with justice,
And policy, and pride, walk like two exiles
Giving attendance, that were once attended,
and we rejected that were once high honoured,
I hate andrea, cause he aims at honour,
when my purest thoughts, work in a pitchy vale,
which are as different as heaven and hell,
One peers for day, the other gaps for night,
That yawning Beldam with her Ieltie skin,
It is she I hug as mine effeminate bride,
For such complexions best appease my pride:
I have a lad in pickle of this stamp,
A melancholy discontented courtier
Whose famished jaws look like the chap of death,
Upon whose eyebrows hang damnation,
Whose hands are washed in rape, and murders bold,
Him with a golden bait will I allure,
For Courtiers will do anything for gold,
To be Andrea's death at his return:
He loves my Sister; that shall cost his life,
So she a husband, he shall lose a wife,
O sweet, sweet policy, I hug thee, good:
Andreas hymen's draught, shall be in blood.

body.stage: Enter Horatio at one doore, Andrea at an other.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Whether in such haste my second self.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: Aye faith my dear bosom, to take solemn leave,
Of a most weeping creature.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: That is a woman.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: That is Bellimperia.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: See see, she meets you here:
And what it is to love? And be loved dear,

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: I have hard of your honour gentle breast,
I do not like it now so well methinks.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: What, not to have honour bestowed on me.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: O yes: But not a wandering honour dear,
I could afford well didst thou stay here,
Could honour melt itself into thy veins,
And thou the fountain, I could wish it so,
If thou wouldst remain here with me: and not go.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: It is but to portugale.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: But to demand the tribute Lady.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Tribute, alas that Spaine, cannot of peace
Forbear, a little coin, the Indies being so near,
And yet this is not all: I know you are too hot,
too full of spleen for an ambassador,
And will lean much to honour.

sp.speaker: and.
sp.l: Push.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Nay hear me dear; I know you will be rough
And violent, and portingale hath a tempestuous son,
Stamped with the mark of fury, and you too.

sp.speaker: and.
sp.l: Sweet Bellimperia.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: We will meet like thunder, catch imperious over
Others spleen you have both proud spirits and both will
strive to a pyre, when two vexed Clouds jostle they strike
Out fire, and you I fear me war, which peace forfend,
O dear andrea pray, let us have no wars,
First let them pay the soldiers, that were maimed
In the last battle, ere more wretches fall,
Or walk on stilts to timeless Funeral.

sp.speaker: and.
sp.l: Respective dear, O my lives happiness,
the joy of all my being, do not shape
Frightful conceit beyond the intent of act,
I know thy love is vigilant over my blood,
And fears ill fate which heaven hath yet withstood,
But be of comfort, sweet Horatio knows,
I go to knit friends, not to kindle foes.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: true Madam Belimperia, that is his task
the phrase he useth must be gently styled,
the king hath warned him to be smooth and mild.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: But will you indeed andrea.

sp.speaker: and.
sp.l: By this.

sp.speaker: And
sp.l: By this lip blushing kiss.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: O you swear sweetly.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I will keep your oath for you till you return.
Then I will be sure you shall not be forsworn.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: Ho Pedringano.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Signiory.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: Are all things aboard.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: They are my good Lord.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: Then Bellimperia. I take leave: Horatio
Be in my absence my dear self, chaste self,
What playing the woman Bellimperia:
Nay then you love me not, or at the least,
You drown my honours in those flowing waters,
Believe it Bellimperia, it is as common,
To weep at parting, as to be a woman,
Love me more valiant, play not this moist prize,
Be woman in all parts, save in thy eyes:
And so I leave thee.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Farewell my Lord:
Be mindful of my love, and of your word.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: It is fixed upon my heart, adieu souls friend.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: All honour, on Andreas steps attend.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Yet he is in sight, and yet but now he is vanished.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Nay Lady if you stoop so much to passion, I will call
him back again.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: O good Horatio, no: it is for honour prithee let
him go.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Then Madam be composed as you were wont,
to music and delight, the time being Comic, will
Seem short and pleasant, till his return
From Portingale: and, madam in this circle,
Let your heart move,
Honoured promotion is the sap of love.

body.stage: Enter Lorenza and lazarotto, a discontented Courtier.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Come my soul's spaniel, my life's jetty substance,
What is thy name?

sp.speaker: Lazarotto
sp.l: My name is an honest name, a Courtiers
Name: it is lazarotto.

sp.speaker: lor.
sp.l: What lazarotto.

sp.speaker: Lazarotto
sp.l: Or rather rotting in this lazy age, that
Yields me no employments, I have mischief
Within my breast more than my bulk can hold,
I want a midwife to deliver it.

sp.speaker: lor.
sp.l: I will be the he one then, and rid thee soon
Of this dull, leaden, and tormenting elf:
Thou knowest the love betwixt Bellimperia and
andreas bosom?

sp.speaker: Lazarotto
sp.l: Aye, I do.

sp.speaker: lor.
sp.l: How might I cross, it, my sweet mischief:
Honey damnation how?

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Well: as many ways as there are paths to hell
And that is enough i'faith: from usurers door
There goes one path, from friars that nurse
Whores, there goes another path: from brokers
Stalls, from rich that die and build no hospitals,
Two other paths: from farmers that crack barns,
With stuffing corn, yet starve the needy swarms,
Another path: from drinking schools one, from
Dicing houses, but from the court, none, none.

sp.speaker: lor.
sp.l: Here is a slave just of the stamp, I wish:
Whose Juck-soul is, blacker than his name,
Though it stand printed with a Ravens quill.
But lazarotto cross, my Sisters love, and I will
Rain showers of Ducats in thy palm.

sp.speaker: Lazarotto
sp.l: O Ducats, dainty ducks forgive me,
Ducats, I will fetch you duck enough for gold,
And think males, the punk wanton and the
Bawd to wink.

sp.speaker: lor.
sp.l: Discharge, discharge, good lazaratto, how we
May cross my Sisters loving hopes.

sp.speaker: Lazarotto
sp.l: Nay? now I will tell you.

sp.speaker: lor.
sp.l: Thou knowest Andrea is gone ambassador.

sp.speaker: Lazarotto
sp.l: The better there is opportunity now list to me.
sp.stage: Enter Ieronimo, and Horatio, and ouer heares their talke.
sp.l: Alcario the duke Medinas son,
Dotes on your Sister Bellimperia,
Him in her private gallery you shall place,
To court her, let his protestations be,
Fashioned with rich Jewels, for in love, great,
Gifts and gold have the best tongue to move,
Let him not spare an oath, without a jewel,
To bind it fast: O I know women's hearts
What stuff they are made of, my Lord:
Gifts and giving, will melt the chasest
Seeming female living.

sp.speaker: lo.
sp.l: Indeed andrea is but poor, though honourable,
His bounty amongst soldiers soaks him dry,
And therefore great gifts may bewitch her eye.

sp.speaker: Iero.
sp.l: Here is no fine villainy, no damned brother?

sp.speaker: lo.
sp.l: But say she should deny his gifts, be all
Composed of hate, as my mind gives me,
that she will: what then?

sp.speaker: Lazarotto
sp.l: Then thus: At his return to spaine, I will
Murder don Andrea.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Darest thou spirit.

sp.speaker: Lazarotto
sp.l: What dares not he do, that near hopes
To Inherit.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: He dares be damned like thee.

sp.speaker: Lazarotto
sp.l: Dare I: Ha, ha, I have no hope of everlasting
Height, my soul is a Moore you know salvation is
White, what dare not I enact then, tush, he dies
I will make way to Bellimperias eyes.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: To weep I fear but not to tender love.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.l: Why is she not a woman, she must weep
A while as widows use till their first sleep
Who in the morrow following will be sold to new,
Before the first are thoroughly cold: So
Bellimperia, For this is common, the more
She weeps, the More she plays the woman.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Come then, however it hap Andrea shall be crossed.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.l: Let me alone, I will turn him to a ghost.

body.stage: Exit Lorenzo, and lazarotto, and Horatio.

sp.speaker: Iero.
sp.l: Farewell true brace of villains,
Come hither boy Horatio, didst thou hear them.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: O my true breasted father, my ears have sucked
In poison, deadly Poison, murder Andrea:
O Inhumane practice, had not your reverend
Years been present here, I should have
Poniarded the villains bowels, and shoved his
Soul out to Damnation, Murder Andrea:
Honest lord: impious villains.

sp.speaker: Iero.
sp.l: I like thy true heart boy, thou lovest thy friend,
It is the greatest argument and sign that I begot thee,
For it shows thou art mine.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: O father: It is a charitable deed,
To prevent those that would make virtue bleed.
I will dispatch letters to don andrea,
Unfold their hellish Practise, damned intent,
Against the virtuous rivers of his life?
Murder andrea.

sp.speaker: Iero.
sp.l: Peace: Who comes here: news news
Isaballa.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: What news Ieronimo ?

sp.speaker: Iero.
sp.l: Strange news, Lorenzo is become an honest man

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Is this your wondrous news.

sp.speaker: Iero.
sp.l: Is it not wondrous to have honesty in hell, go, tell
It Abroad now, but see you put no new additions
To it: as thus, shall I tell you gossip: Lorenzo,
Is become an honest man: Beware, beware,
For honesty spoken in derision points out knavery.
O then take heed, that Jest would not be trim,
He is a great man, therefore we must not knave him.
In gentle soul, I will not be long away,
As short my body, Short shall be my stay.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Murder andrea: What blood-sucking slave
Could choke bright honour in a scabbard grave,

sp.speaker: Iero.
sp.l: What harping still upon anadreas death,
Have courage boy: I shall prevent their plots,
And make them both stand like too politic sots.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Lorenzo has a reach as far as hell,
To hook the devil from his flaming cell:
O sprightly father he will outreach you then,
Knaves, longer reaches have the honest men.

sp.speaker: Iero.
sp.l: But boy fear not, I will out-stretch them all
My mind is a giant, though my bulk be full.

body.stage: Enter the king of Portingale Balthezer, alexandro, Donne Vollupo, and others: apeale of ordenance, within a great shout of people

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What is the meaning of this loud report

sp.speaker: alex.
sp.l: An embassador. my Lord is new arrived from spaine.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Son Balthezer we pray do you go meet him,
And do him all the honour that belongs him.

sp.speaker: Ball.
sp.l: Father my best endeavour shall obey you,
Welcome worthy lord, spaines choice ambassador,
Brave stout, andrea, for so I guess thee.

sp.speaker: and.
sp.l: Portugalles eire I thank thee,
Thou seems no less than what thou art, a prince:
And an heroic spirit, Portingalles king,
I kiss my hand, and tender on thy throne,
My masters love, peace, and affection.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: And we receive them, and thee worthy andrea:
Thy masters high prised love unto our heart,
Is welcome to his friend thou to our court.

sp.speaker: and.
sp.l: Thanks Portingall: My lords I had in charge
At my depart from spaine this embassage,
To put your breast in mind of tribute due
Unto our masters kingdom, these three years
Detained and kept back: and I sent to know,
Whether neglect, or will detains it so.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Thus much return unto thy king andrea,
We have with best advise thought of our state,
And find it much dishonoured by base homage,
I not deny but tribute hath been due to Spaine,
By our forefathers base captivity,
Yet cannot raze out their successors merit:
It is said we shall not answer at next birth
Our fathers faults, in heaven, why then on earth:
Which proves and shows that which they lost
by base Captivity,
We may redeem with honoured valiancy,
We borrow naught, our kingdom is our own,
He is a base king that pays rent for his throne.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: Is this thy answer Portingalle:

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: Aye spaine, a royal answer too, which I will maintain.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: And all the peers of Portugalle the like.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: Then thus all spaine which but three minutes,
ago was thy full friend, is now returned thy foe.

sp.speaker: Ball.
sp.l: An excellent foe, we shall have scuffling good.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: Thou shalt pay tribute, Portugalle with blood.

sp.speaker: Ball.
sp.l: Tribute for tribute then: And foes, for foes.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: I bid you sudden wars.

sp.speaker: Ball.
sp.l: Aye sudden blows, and that is as good as wars
Don, I will not bate,
An inch of courage nor a hair of fate,
Pay tribute I with strokes.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: Aye with strokes you shall
Alas that spaine should correct Portugal.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: Correct: O in that one word, such torments do,
I feele that I could lash thy ribs with valiant steel.

sp.speaker: and.
sp.l: Prince Balthezer, shall us meet?

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: Meet don Andrea, yes in the battles Bowels:
Here is my gage a never failing pawn.
it will keep his day his hour, nay minute: It will.

sp.speaker: and.
sp.l: Then thine, and this posses one quality

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: O let them kiss, did I not understand thee noble
Valiant, and worthy my swords society with thee,
For all Spaines wealth. I would not grasp hands
Meet Don andrea. I tell thee noble spirit
I would wade up to the knees in blood,
I would make a bridge of spanish carcasses
to single thee, out of the gasping army.

sp.speaker: and.
sp.l: Would thou prince: why even for that I love.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: Tut, love me man when we have drunk,
Hot blood together, wounds will tie
an everlasting settled amity.
And so shall thine.

sp.speaker: and.
sp.l: And thine.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: What give no place?

sp.speaker: and.
sp.l: to whom.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: to me.

sp.speaker: and.
sp.l: To thee: why should my face,
that is placed above my mind,
Fall under it.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: I will make thee yield,

sp.speaker: and.
sp.l: Aye when you get me down,
But I stand even yet, jump crown to crown.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: Darest thou?

sp.speaker: and.
sp.l: I dare

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: I am all vexed.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: I care not.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: I shall forget the Law.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: Do, do.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: Shall I?

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: Spare not?

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: But thou wilt yield first.

sp.speaker: and.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: O, I hug thee for it
the valiantest spirit ere trod the Spanish court,
Here let the rising of our hot blood set.

sp.speaker: alex.
sp.l: My liege two nobler spirits never met.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: Until we meet in purple, when our swords,

sp.speaker: and.
sp.l: Agreed, right valiant prince:
Then Portugale this is thy resolute answer.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: So return: it is so, we have bethought us what
Tribute is, how poor that Monarch shoes,
Who for his throne a yearly pension owes:
And what our predecessors lost to spaine,
We have fresh spirits that can renew it again.

sp.speaker: and.
sp.l: Then I unclasp the purple leaves of war,
Many a new wound must gasp, through an old scar:
So Portugale I leave thee.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Ourself in person will see thee safe aboard:
Come son, come Lords,
Instead of tribute we must pay our swords.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: Remember Don andrea that we meet.

sp.speaker: and.
sp.l: Up hither sailing in a crimson fleet.

sp.speaker: lo.
sp.l: Do you affect my Sister.

sp.speaker: alca.
sp.l: Affect, above affection: for her breast,
Is my lives treasure, O entire
Is the condition of my hot desire.

sp.speaker: lo.
sp.l: Then this must be your plot,
You know andrea is gone ambassador,
On whom my Sister Bellimperia,
Casts her affection: you are in stature like him,
Speech alike, and had you but his vestment
On your back, there is no-one living but would
Swear it were he: therefore, sly policy must
Be your guide, I have a suite just
Of andreas, colours, proportioned in all parts,
Nay it was his own: this suit within my closet,
Shall you wear, and so disguised woe, sue, and
Then at last.

sp.speaker: alca.
sp.l: What.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Obtain my love.

sp.speaker: alca.
sp.l: This falls out rare,
In this disguise I may both wed, bed, and board her.

sp.speaker: lor.
sp.l: You may you may? besides, within these few days
He will return.

sp.speaker: alca.
sp.l: Till this be acted I in passion burn.

sp.speaker: lor.
sp.l: All falls out for the purpose, all hits jump,
The date of his embassage nigh expired,
Gives strength unto our plot.

sp.speaker: alca.
sp.l: True, true, all to the purpose.

sp.speaker: lor.
sp.l: Moreover, I will buzz Andreas Landing,
which once but crept into the vulgar mouths,
Is hurried here, and there, and sworn for troth,
Think it is your love makes me create this guise,
And willing hope to see your virtue rise.

sp.speaker: alca.
sp.l: Lorenzoes bounty I do more enfold,
Than the greatest mind of indians brightest gold.

sp.speaker: lo.
sp.l: Come let us in, the next time you shall show,
All Don andrea, not alcario.

body.stage: Enter Ieronimo trussing of his points, Horatio with pen and incke.

sp.speaker: Iero.
sp.l: Come pull the table this way, so it is well:
Come write horatio write,
This speedy letter must away tonight.
sp.stage: horatio foulds the paper the contrary way.
sp.l: What fold paper that way, to a noble man,
to Don andrea Spaines ambassador?
Fie I am ashamed to see it,
Hast thou worn gowns in the University,
Lost logic, sucked Philosophy,
Eat Q's, drink C's, and cannot
give A letter the right Courtiers crest:
O there is a kind of state,
In everything save in a Cuckolds pate,
Fie, fie, horatio, what is your pen foul.

sp.speaker: ho.
sp.l: No Father cleaner than lorenzoes soul,
That is dipped in ink made of an envious gall,
Else had my pen no cause to write at all.

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.l: Seignior andrea say.

sp.speaker: ho.
sp.l: Seignior andrea.

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.l: it is a villainous age this.

sp.speaker: hor.
sp.l: it is a villainous age this.

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.l: That a nobleman should be a knave, as
Well as an Ostler.

sp.speaker: ho.
sp.l: That a nobleman should be a knave, as
Well as an Ostler.

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.l: Or a sergeant.

sp.speaker: ho.
sp.l: Or a sergeant.

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.l: Or a Broker.

sp.speaker: ho.
sp.l: Or a Broker.

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.l: Yet I speak not this of lorenzo,
For he is an honest Lord.

sp.speaker: ho.
sp.l: 'sfoot, Father I will not write him honest Lord.

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.l: take up thy pen, or I will take up thee.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: What write him honest Lord I will not agree.

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.l: You will take it up Sir.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Well, well.

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.l: what went before, thou hast put me out, beshrew
thy impudence or insolence.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Lorenzo is an honest Lord.

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.l: well Sir, and has hired one to murder you.

sp.speaker: ho.
sp.l: O, I cry you mercy Father, meant you so.

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.l: Art thou a scholar Don horatio?
And canst not aim at Figurative speech.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I pray you pardon me, it was but youths
Hasty error.

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.l: Come read then?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: And has hired one to murder you.

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.l: He means to send you to heaven, when
You return from Portugale.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: From portugale.

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.l: Yet he is an honest dukes son.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Yet he is an

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.l: But not the honest son of a Duke.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: But not the honest.

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.l: O that villainy should be found in the great
Chamber.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: O that villainy.

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.l: And honesty in the bottom of a seller.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: And honesty.

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.l: If you will be murdered you may?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: If you will be

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.l: If you be not, thank God, and Ieronimo.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: If you be not.

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.l: If you be, thank the devil and lorenzo.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: If you be thank.

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.l: Thus hoping you will not be murdered and you
Can choose.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Thus hoping you will.

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.l: Especially being warned before hand.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Especially
I take my leave boy, Horatio, write leave,
Bending in the hams like an old Courtier,
Thy assured friend say, against lorenza and
The devil, little Ieronimo Marshall.

sp.speaker: ho.
sp.l: Ieronimo Marshall.

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.l: So now read it over.

sp.speaker: ho.
sp.l: Seignior andrea it is a villainous age this,
That a Nobleman should be a knave, as well
As an Ostler: or a Sergeant, or a broker, yet
I speak not this of Lorenzo: he is an
Honest Lord, and has hired one to murder you,
When you return from Portugale, yet
He is an honest Dukes son, but not the
Honest son of a Duke? O that villainy
Should be found in the great chamber, and honesty
In the bottom of a seller.

sp.speaker: Iero.
sp.l: True boy: there is a moral in that, as much
To say knavery in the Court and honesty in a
Cheese house.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: If you will be murdered you may: if you be
Not thank God and Ieronimo: if you be,
Thank the devil and Lorenzo. Thus hoping
You will not be murdered, and you can choose,
Especially being warned before hand, I take my leave.

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.l: Horatio hast thou written leave bending in the
Hams: enough like a Gentleman usher. 'sfoot
No Horatio, thou hast made him straddle too much,
Like a Frenchman, for shame put his legs closer
Though it be painful.
Ho:
So: it is done, it is done.
Thy assured friend against Lorenza, and the devil,
Little Ieronimo, Marshall.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Yonder he is my Lord pray you speak to him.

sp.speaker: Iero.
sp.l: Wax, wax Horatio: I had need wax two,
Our foes will stride else over me and you?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: He is writing a love letter to some Spanish Lady,
And now he calls for wax to seal it.

sp.speaker: lor.
sp.l: God save you good knight Marshall.

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.l: Who is this, my Lord lorenzo: welcome, welcome,
You are the last man I thought on, save the devil.
Much doth your presence grace our homely roof.

sp.speaker: lor.
sp.l: O Ieronimo, your wife condemns you of a uncourtesy,
And over-passing wrong, and more she names
Love letters which you send to spanish Dames.

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.l: Do you accuse me so kind Isabella.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Unkind Ieronimo.

sp.speaker: lor.
sp.l: And for my instance this in your hand is one.

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.l: In sooth my Lord there is no written name
Of any Lady, then no spanish dame.

sp.speaker: lor.
sp.l: If it were not so, you would not be afeared
To read or show the waxed letter:
Pray you let me behold it.

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.l: I pray you pardon me
I must confess my Lord, it treats of love,
Love to andrea, aye even to his very bosom.

sp.speaker: lor.
sp.l: What news my Lord hear you from portugale.

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.l: Who I, before your grace it must not be,
The Badger feeds not till the lion is served,
Nor fits it news so soon kiss subjects,
As the fair cheek of high authority:
Ieronimo lives much absent from the Court,
And being absent, there lives from report.

sp.speaker: lor.
sp.l: Farewell Ieronimo.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: welcome my Lord Lorenzo.

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.l: Boy thy mother is jealous of my love to her,

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: O she played us a wise part, now ten to one
He had not overheard the letter read, just as he entered.

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.l: Though it had happened evil,
He should have hard his name yoked with the devil,
Here seal the letter with a loving knot,
Send it with speed, Horatio linger not:
That Don andrea, may prevent his death,
And know his enemy by his envious breath.

body.stage: Enter Lorenzo, and Alcario, disguisd like Andrea.

sp.speaker: lor.
sp.l: Now by the honour of Casteels true house,
You are as like andrea, part for part,
as he is like himself: did I know you,
By my cross I swear: I could not think you
But Andreas self, so legged, so faced, so
Speeched, so all in all: methinks, I should salute
Your quick return and speedy haste from portugale,
Welcome fair Lord, worthy ambassador,
Brave Don andrea; O I laugh to see
How we shall jest at her mistaking thee.

sp.speaker: alca.
sp.l: What have you given it out andrea is returned?

sp.speaker: lo.
sp.l: It is all about the court in every ear,
And my invention, brought to me for news,
Last night at supper, and which the more to cover,
I took a bowl and quaffed a health to him,
When it would scarce go down for extreme laughter,
to think how soon report had scattered it.

sp.speaker: alca.
sp.l: But is the villain Lazarotto acquainted with
our drift.

sp.speaker: lo.
sp.l: Not for Spains wealth,
though he be secret, yet suspects the worst,
For confidence confounds the stratagem,
the fewer in a plot of jealousy,
Build a foundation surest, when multitudes
Makes it confused ere it come to head,
Be secret then, trust not the open air,
For air is breath, and breath blown words raise care:
this is the gallery where she most frequents,
Within this walk have I beheld her dally,
With my shapes substance, O immortal powers.
Lend your assistance, clap a silver tongue within
This palate, that when I approach,
Within the presence of this demi Goddess,
I may posses an adamitic power,
And so bewitch her with my honeyed speech,
Have every syllable a music stop,
that when I pause the melody may move,
And hem persuasion between her snowy paps
that her heart hearing may relent and yield.

sp.speaker: lor.
sp.l: Break off my Lord, see where she makes approach.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.l: then fall into your former veins of terms:

sp.speaker: lor.
sp.l: Welcome my Lord, welcome brave Don
Andrea, Spaines best of spirit: what news,
From Portugale tribute or war,
But see my Sister Bellimperia comes,
I will defer it till some other time,
For company hinders love's conference.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Welcome my life's self form, dear Don Andrea,

sp.speaker: alca.
sp.l: My words iterated gives thee as much,
Welcome my self, of self.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: What news Andrea ? treats it peace or war?

sp.speaker: alca.
sp.l: At first they cried all war, as men resolved
to loose both life and honour at one cast:
At which I thundered words all clad in proof,
Which struck amazement to their palled speech,
And tribute presently was yielded up.
But madam Bellimperia leave we this,
And talk of former suites and quests of love.

sp.speaker: Lazarotto
sp.l: it is all about the Court Andrea is come,
Would I might greet him and I wonder much
My Lord lorenzo is so slack in murder,
Not to afford me notice all this while.
Gold I am true I had my hire,
And thou shalt have thy due:
Was itWast possible to miss him so, soft, soft,
this gallery leads to Bellimpesias lodging,
there he is sure, or will be sure. I will stay;
the evening too begins to slobber day,
Sweet opportuneful season here I will lean,
Like a court hound that licks fat trenchers clean.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: But has the king partook your embassy.

sp.speaker: alca.
sp.l: that till tomorrow shall be now deferred.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Nay then you love me not,
Let that be first dispatch,
till when receive this token.

sp.speaker: alca.
sp.l: I to the king with this unfaithful heart,
It must not be, I play too false a part.

sp.speaker: Lazarotto
sp.l: Up lazarotto, yonder comes thy prize,
Now lives Andrea, now Andrea dies.

sp.speaker: alca.
sp.l: that villain lazarotto has killed me
Instead of andrea.

body.stage: Enter andrea, and Rogero, and other

sp.speaker: Roge.
sp.l: Welcome home Lord ambassador.

sp.speaker: alca.
sp.l: O, O, O.

sp.speaker: and.
sp.l: Whose groan was that, what frightful villain is this,
His sword unsheathed, whom hast thou murdered slave?

sp.speaker: Lazarotto
sp.l: Why Don, Don andrea?

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: No counterfeiting villain,
He says my Lord that he hath murdered me.

sp.speaker: Lazarotto
sp.l: Aye Don Andrea, or else Don the devil.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: Lay hands On him, some rear up the bleeding
Body to the light.

sp.speaker: Roge.
sp.l: My Lord I think it is you, were you not here
A man might swear it were you.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: His garments ha like mine, his face made like:
An ominous horror, all my veins doth strike,
Sure this pretends my death, this misery
Aims at some fatal pointed tragedy.

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.l: Son Horatio see Andrea slain.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: andrea slain, then weapon cling my breast.

sp.speaker: and.
sp.l: Live truest friend forever loved and blessed.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Lives Don andrea.

sp.speaker: and.
sp.l: Aye but slain in thought,
To see so strange a likeness forged and wrought,
Lords cannot you yet descry
Who is the owner, of this red melting body.

sp.speaker: Roge.
sp.l: My Lord it is alcario Duke Medinas son,
I know him by this mold upon his breast.

sp.speaker: Lazarotto
sp.l: alcario slain, hast thou beguiled me sword?
Arm hast thou slain thy bountiful kind lord,
Why then rot off, and drop upon the ground,
Strew all the galleries with gobbets round.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Who names Alcario slain, it is Alcario,
O cursed deed, couldst thou not see,
But make the wrong man bleed.

sp.speaker: Lazarotto
sp.l: 'sfoot it was your fault my lord, you brought no word.

sp.speaker: lor.
sp.l: Peace, no words, I will get thy pardon.
Why mum then.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Who names Andrea slain, O it is andrea,
O I sound I die.

sp.speaker: lor.
sp.l: Look to my Sister Bellimperia.

sp.speaker: and.
sp.l: Raise up my dear love, Bellimperia,
O be of comfort sweet, call in thy spirits,
Andrea lives O let not death beguile thee.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: Are you Andrea.

sp.speaker: and.
sp.l: Do not forget, that was alcario
My shapes counterfeit.

sp.speaker: lor.
sp.l: Why speaks not this accursed damned villain.

sp.speaker: Lazarotto
sp.l: O good words my Lords, for those are courtiers veils,
The king must hear why should I make
Two tails, for to be found in two,
Before the king I will resolve you all,
This strange strange thing, I hot, yet missed,
It was I mistook my part.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Aye villain: for thou aimest at this true heart.

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.l: Horatio it was well as fortune stands.
This letter came not to Andreas hands.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: It was happiness indeed.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Was it not you Andrea questioned me about love?

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: No Bellimperia, belike it was false Andrea,
For the first object mine eyes met,
Was that most accursed
witch, I much fear me by all signs pretend
Most doubtful wars and dangerous pointed ends
To light upon my blood.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Angels of heaven forfend it.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: Some take up the body, others take charge
Of that accursed villain.

sp.speaker: lor.
sp.l: My Lord leave that to me, I will look to him.

sp.speaker: Ier,
sp.l: Mark, mark, Horatio: a villain guard a villain.

sp.speaker: and.
sp.l: The king may think my news is a bad guest,
When the first object is a bleeding breast.

body.stage: Enter King of Spaine, Castile, Medina, Rogero, and others, a dead martch within.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: My Lords, what heavy sounds are these?
Nearer, and nearer, ha andrea the forerunner
Of these news, nay then I fear spaines
Inevitable ill
Ha andrea speak, what news from Portugale?
What is tribute paid: peace, or wars.

sp.speaker: and.
sp.l: Wars my dread liege.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Why then that bleeding object
doth presage what shall hereafter follow:
What is he that lies there slain, or hurt,
Or both: speak?

sp.speaker: and.
sp.l: My liege, alcario Duke medinas son,
And by that slave this purple act was done.

sp.speaker: Medi.
sp.l: Who names Alcario slain: ay me it is he?
Art thou that villain.

sp.speaker: Lazarotto
sp.l: How didst know my name.
I see an excellent villain hath his fame
As well as a great courtier.

sp.speaker: Medi.
sp.l: Speak villain, wherefore didst thou this accursed deed.

sp.speaker: Lazarotto
sp.l: Because I was an ass, a villainous ass,
For had I hot it right, Andrea had line there:
He walked upright, this ominous mistake,
This damned error breeds in my soul
An everlasting terror.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Say slave, how came this accursed evil?

sp.speaker: Lazarotto
sp.l: Faith by myself, my short sword, and the devil,
To tell you all without a tedious tongue,
I will cut them down, my words shall not hang,
That hapless bleeding Lord alcario
Which this hand slew, pox on it, was a huge doter
On Bellimperias beauty who replied in scorn
And his hot suite denied:
For her affections were all firmly planted,
In Don andreas bosom, yet unwise,
He still pursued it with blind lovers eyes:
Then hired he me with gold: O fate thou elf,
To kill Andrea which hire killed himself.
For not content to stay the time of murder,
He took andreas shape unknown to me,
And in all parts disguised as there you see,
Intending as it seemed by that sly shift,
To steal away her troth: short tale to tell,
I took him for Andrea, down he fell.

sp.speaker: king.
sp.l: O impious deed, to make the heir of honour
Melt and bleed, bear him away to execution.

sp.speaker: Lazarotto
sp.l: Nay Lord Lorenzo, where is the pardon?
'sfoot I will peach else.

sp.speaker: lor,
sp.l: Peace Lazarotto, I will get it of the king.

sp.speaker: Lazarotto
sp.l: Do it quickly then or I will spread villainy.

sp.speaker: lor.
sp.l: My Lord he is the most notorious rogue
That ever breathed.
In his ear.

sp.speaker: king.
sp.l: Away with him.

sp.speaker: lor.
sp.l: Your highness may do well to bar his speech,
It is able to infect a virtuous ear.

sp.speaker: king.
sp.l: Away with him I will not hear him speak

sp.speaker: Lazarotto
sp.l: My Lord Lorenzo is a

body.stage: They stop his mouth and beare him in.

sp.speaker: Iero.
sp.l: Is not this a monstrous courtier.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: He is the court toad father,

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Tribute denied us ha.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: It is my liege, and that with no mean words
He will redeem his honour lost with swords.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: So daring: Ha, so Peremptory,
Can you remember the words he spake?

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: Word for word my gracious sovereign,
And these they were: Thus much return to Spaine,
Say: That our settled Judgment hath advised us,
What tribute is, how poor that Monarch shows,
Who for his throne a yearly pension owes,
And what our predecessors lost to Spaine,
We have fresh spirits that can renew it again.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Ha so peremptory, daring, stout.

sp.speaker: and.
sp.l: Then my liege, according your gracious dread,
Command,
I bad defiance with, a vengeful hand.

sp.speaker: Spai.
sp.l: He entertained it.

sp.speaker: and.
sp.l: Aye and returned it with menacing brows,
Prince Baltheser his son,
Grew Violent and wished the fight begun.

sp.speaker: lor.
sp.l: So, so, I have sent my slave to hell:
Though he blab there, the devils will not tell.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.l: How now, what means this trumpets sound?
My liege, the Portugalles.

sp.speaker: mess.
sp.l: Are up in arms glittering in steel.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.l: Where is our lord general, lorenzo, stout andrea,
With whom I rank sprightly Horatio.
What for shame, shall the Portugalles
Trample the fields before you.

sp.speaker: Gene.
sp.l: No my liege, there is time enough
To let out blood enough, tribute shall flow,
Out of their bowels, and be tendered so.

sp.speaker: Spai.
sp.l: Farewell brave Lords, my wishes are bequeathed
A nobler rank of spirits never breathed.

sp.speaker: Iero.
sp.l: O my sweet boy, heaven shield thee still from care,
O be as fortunate as thee art fair.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: And heaven bless you my father in this fight,
that I may see your Gray head crowned in white.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: You came but now, must you part again.
You told me that your spirit
Should put on peace but see war follows war.

sp.speaker: and.
sp.l: Nay sweet love cease,
to be denied our honour why it were base,
to breath and live, and wars in such a case,
Is even as necessary as our blood,
Swords are in season then, when right is withstood,
Deny us tribute, that so many years,
We have in peace told out,
Why it would raise spleen in the host
Of Angels: it were enough
to make tranquil saints of angry stuff.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: You have over-wrought the chiding of my breast,
And by that argument, you firmly prove
Honour to sore above the pitch of love.
Lend me thy loving and thy warlike arm,
On which I knit this soft and silken charm,
Tied with an amorous knot, O may it prove
Enchanted armour, being charmed by love,
That when it mounts up to thy warlike crest,
It may put by the sword, and so be blessed.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: O what divinity proceeds from love?
What happier fortune than myself can move,
Hark, the drum beckons me; sweet dear farewell,
This scarf shall be my charm, against foes and hell.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: O let me kiss thee first.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: The drum again.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Hath that more power than I?

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: Do it quickly then: farewell.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Farewell O cruel part,
andreas bosom bears away my heart.

body.stage: Enter Balthezer, alexandro, Vollupo, Don Pedro, with soldiers, drum and coullers.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: Come valiant spirits you Peers of Portugale,
That owe your lives, your faiths, and services,
To set you free from base captivity:
O let our fathers scandal never be seen,
As a base blush upon our free born cheeks,
Let all the tribute that proud Spaine received,
Of those all captive Portugales deceased,
Turn into chafe, and choke their insolence:
Methinks no, moiety not one little thought,
Of them whose servile acts live in their graves,
But should raise spleens big as a cannon bullet,
Within your bosoms: O for honour,
Your countries reputation, your lives freedom,
Indeed your all, that may be termed revenge,
Now let your bloods be liberal as the sea:
And all those wounds that you receive of Spaine,
Let theirs be equal to quit yours again,
Speak portugales: are you resolved as I,
to live like captives, or as free born die.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.l: Prince Balthezer as you say, so say we,
to die with honour, scorn captivity.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Why spoke like true Portugales indeed,
I am assured of your forwardness:
Now Spaine sit firm, I will make thy towers shake,
And all that gold thou hadst from Portugale,
which makes thy court melt in Luxuriousness.
I vow to have it treble at thy hands,
Hark Portugales: I hear their spanish drum,
March on and meet them: this must be the day,
that all they have received, they back must pay.

body.stage: Enter Ieronimo, Andrea, Horatio, lorenzo, lord Generall, Rogero, and attendants with drum and Coullers.

sp.speaker: Iero.
sp.l: What are you braving us before we come,
we will be as shrill as you: strike a larum drum.

body.stage: They sound a florish a both sides.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: Thou inch of Spaine,
Thou man from thy hose downward,
Scarce so much: thou very little longer than
Thy beard: speak not such big words,
They will throw thee down little Ieronimo,
words greater than thyself, it must not.

sp.speaker: Iero.
sp.l: And thou long thing of Portugale, why not
Thou, that art full as tall
As an English gallows: upper beam and all:
Devourer of apparel thou huge swallower,
My hose will scarce make thee a standing collar,
What? Have I almost quited you?

sp.speaker: and.
sp.l: Have done impatient Marshall.

sp.speaker: bal.
sp.l: Spanish combatants, what do you set a little
Pygnire Marshall so question with a Prince?

sp.speaker: and.
sp.l: No prince Balthezer, I have desired him peace,
That we might war: What is the tribute,
Money tendered yet?

sp.speaker: bal.
sp.l: Tribute ha, ha, what else wherefore meet our
Drums but to tender and receive the sums,
Of many a bleeding heart which ere Sun fall,
Shall pay dear tribute, even there lives and all.

sp.speaker: and.
sp.l: Prince balthezer, I know your valiant spirit,
I know your carriage to be trite and good,
Yet, O prince, be not confirmed in blood,
Not that I taste of fear or cowardice,
But of religion piety, and love,
To many bosoms, that yet firmly move,
Without disturbed spleens: O in thy heart,
Weigh the dear drops of many a purple part,
That must be acted on the fields green stage,
Before the evening dews quench the sons rage,
Let tribute be appeased, and so stayed,
And let not wonted fealty be denied,
To our desert full kingdom: portugales,
Keep your forefathers Oaths; that virtue craves,
Let them not lie forsworn now in their graves,
To make their ashes perjured, and unjust,
For heaven can be revenged on their dust,
They swore to Spaine both for themselves and you,
And will posterity prove their sires untrue,
This should not be among men of virtuous spirit
Pay tribute thou, and receive peace and writ.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: O virtuous coward?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: O ignoble spirit?
To term him coward for his virtuous merit!

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: Coward, nay then: relentless rib of steel,
What virtue cannot, thou shalt make him feele.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Proud Alexandro thou art mine?

sp.speaker: alex.
sp.l: Agreed.

sp.speaker: Roge.
sp.l: And thou Vullupo mine?

sp.speaker: Vul.
sp.l: I will make thee bleed.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: And thou Don Pedro mine?

sp.speaker: Don Ped.
sp.l: I care not whose, or thine, or thine, or all at once.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: I bind thee Don Andrea, by thy honour, thy valiancy,
And all that thou holdest great,
To meet me single in the battles heat,
Where I will set down, in Characters upon thy flesh,
Four precious lines, spoke by our fathers mouth
When first thou camest ambassador: these they are:
It is said we shall not answer at next birth
Our Fathers faults in heaven why then on earth,
Which proves and shows, that what they
Lost by base Captivity,
We may redeem with wonted Valliancy.
And to this crimson end our Coullers spread
Our courage are new born our valours bred,
Therefore Andrea as thou tenderest fame,
Wars reputation, and a Soldiers name. meet me?

sp.speaker: and.
sp.l: I will.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: Single me out.

sp.speaker: and.
sp.l: I shall.

sp.speaker: alex.
sp.l: Do you the like?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: And you.
All and we.

sp.speaker: and.
sp.l: Can we be foes, and all so well agreed.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: Why man in war there is bleeding amity,
And he this day gives me the deepest wound,
I will call him brother.

sp.speaker: and.
sp.l: The prince call me so,
To gain that name I will give the deepest blow.

sp.speaker: Iero.
sp.l: Nay then if brother-hood by strokes come dew,
I hope boy thou wilt gain a brother too.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Father I doubt it not.

sp.speaker: and.
sp.l: Lord General, breath like your name,
A General defiance against portugale.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Defiance to the Portugales.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: the like breath our Lord General against the spaniards

sp.speaker: Gene.
sp.l: Defiance to the Spaniards.

sp.speaker: and.
sp.l: Now cease words,
I long to hear the music of clashed swords,

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: why thou shalt hear it presently.

sp.speaker: and.
sp.l: Quickly then.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: Why now.

sp.speaker: Gene.
sp.l: O stay my Lords,
This will but breed a mutiny in the camp.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: I am all fire, andrea.

sp.speaker: and.
sp.l: Art thou, good.
Why then I will quench thee prince, with thine own blood.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: Adieu.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: Adieu.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: Let us meet.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: It is meet we did.

sp.speaker: lo.
sp.l: Alexandro.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: lorenzo.

sp.speaker: Roge.
sp.l: Vollupo.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.l: Rogero.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Don Pedro.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro.
sp.l: Horatio.

sp.speaker: Iero.
sp.l: Aye, aye, Don Pedro my boy shall meet thee,
Come valiant spirits of Spaine,
Valiant Andrea, fortunate lorenzo, worthy Rogero,
Sprightly Horatio, O let me dwell a little on that name,
Be all as fortunate as heavens blessed host,
But blame me not, I would have Horatio most,
Ride all Conquerors when the fight is done,
Especially ride thee home so my son:
So, now kiss and embrace, come, come,
I am wars tutor, strike a larum drum.

body.stage: After a long alarum, the Portugales and Spaniards meete, The Portugales are put to the worst. Enter Ieronimo Solus.

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.l: O valiant boy, struck with a Giants arm,
His sword so falls upon the Portugales,
As if he would slice them out like Oranges,
And squeeze their bloods out: O abundant joy,
Never had father a more happier boy.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: Can you not find Don andrea forth,
O for a voice shriller than all the trumpets,
To prince Andreas ears! through the hot army,
Go search again, bring him or never return.
Valiant Andrea, by thy worthy blood,
Thy honoured faith, which thou pawnest to mine,
By all that thou holdest dear upon this earth,
Sweat now to find me in the hight of blood,
Now death doth heap her goods up all at once,
And crams his store house to the top with blood,
Might I now and andrea in one fight,
Make up thy wardrobe Richer by a knight.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: Who is that andrea.

sp.speaker: Roge.
sp.l: Ha, Vullupo.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: No, but a better,

sp.speaker: roge,
sp.l: Pox on it.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: Pies on it, what luck is this, but Sir
You part not, so, whatever you be, I will have
A bout with you?

sp.speaker: Roge.
sp.l: Content: this is joy mixed with spite,
To miss a Lord and meet a prince in fight.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: Come meet me Sir.

sp.speaker: Roge.
sp.l: Just half way, I will meet it with my sword.

body.stage: They fight, Balthezer beats in rogero. Enter andrea with a Captaine.

sp.speaker: and.
sp.l: Where might I find this valorous balthezer,
This fierce, courageous Prince, a noble, worthy,
Made of the ribs of mars and fortitude,
He promised to meet fair, and single me
Out of the misty battle: did you search
The left wing for him? speak:

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: We did my Lord.

sp.speaker: and.
sp.l: And could he not be found.

sp.speaker: cap.
sp.l: Not in that wing my Lord.

sp.speaker: and.
sp.l: Why this would vex the resolution
Of a suffering spleen: Prince Balthezer,
Portugals valiant heir
The glory of our foe, the heart of courage,
The very soul of true nobility:
I call thee by thy right name answer me,
Go Captain pass the leafed wing squadron, hie,
Mingle yourself again amidst the army,
Pray sweat to find him out.
This place I will keep,
Now wounds are wide, and blood is very deep,
It is now about the heavy dread of battle,
Soldiers drop down as thick as if death mowed them,
As scythe-men trim the long haired Ruffian fields,
So fast they fall: so fast to fate life yields.

sp.speaker: bal.
sp.l: I have sweat much, yet cannot find him andrea.

sp.speaker: and.
sp.l: Prince Balthezer: O lucky minute?

sp.speaker: bal.
sp.l: O long wished-for hour,
Are you remembered Don, of a daring message
And a proud attempt, you braved me Don
Within my Fathers court.

sp.speaker: and.
sp.l: I think I did.

sp.speaker: bal.
sp.l: this sword shall lash you for it.

sp.speaker: and.
sp.l: Alas, war knows I am too proud a scholar grown,
Now to be lashed with steel had I not known
My strength, and courage it had been easy then,
to have me borne upon the backs of men,
But now I am sorry Prince you come too late,
that were proud steel i'faith that should do that.

sp.speaker: bal.
sp.l: I can hold no longer:
Come, come let us see which of our strengths is stronger.

sp.speaker: and.
sp.l: Mine for a wager.

sp.speaker: bal.
sp.l: thine: what wager, say,

sp.speaker: and.
sp.l: I hold three wounds to one.

sp.speaker: bal.
sp.l: Content, a lay; but you shall keep stakes then.

sp.speaker: and.
sp.l: Nay I will trust you.

sp.speaker: and.
sp.l: For you are a prince, I know you will pay your dew.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: I will pay it you soundly.

sp.speaker: and.
sp.l: Prince you might have paid
Tribute as well, then battles had been staid.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: Here is tribute for you.

sp.speaker: and.
sp.l: I will receive it of you,
And give you acquittance with a wound or two

body.stage: They fight, Balthezer hath andrea downe. Enter Ieronimo and Horatio, Horatio beats away Balthezer.

sp.speaker: and.
sp.l: Thou art a wondrous friend, a happy spirit,
I owe thee now my life couldst thou inherit,
Within my bosom, all I have is thine,
For by this act I hold thy arm divine.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Are you not wounded: let me search and see?

sp.speaker: and.
sp.l: No my dear self, for I was blessed by thee,
Else his unpitying sword had cleft my heart,
Had not Horatio played some Angels part.
Come happy mortal, let me rank by thee,
Then am I sure no star will threaten me.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Let us to the battle once more, we may meet.
This haughty prince, and wound him at our feet.

body.stage: Enter Rogero and alexandro in their shirts with Pollaxes.

sp.speaker: Roge.
sp.l: art thou true valiant? hast thou no
Cote of proof girt to thy loins?
art thou true loyal?

sp.speaker: alex.
sp.l: Why look: witness the naked truth,
Upon my breast, come let us meet
Let us meet and break our haughty skulls
Down to our feet.

body.stage: They fight alexandro, beats in Rogero.
Enter Lorenzo and Don Pedro at one dore, and alexandro and Rogero at another dore, lorenzo kils Don Pedro, and alexandro kils Rogero. Enter at one doore andrea, at another doore Balthezer.

sp.speaker: and.
sp.l: O me, ill stead, valiant rogero slain.

sp.speaker: bal.
sp.l: O my sad fates, Don Pedro weltering in his gore.
O could I meet andrea, now my blood is a-tiptoe.
This hand and sword should melt him:
Valiant Don Pedro.

sp.speaker: and.
sp.l: Worthy rogero, sure it was multitudes
That made thee stoop to death,
One Portugale could never overwhelm thee
In such crimson streams,
And no mean blood shall quit it,
balthezer prince balthezer.

sp.speaker: bal.
sp.l: andrea, we meet in blood now.

sp.speaker: and.
sp.l: Aye in valiant blood, of Don rogeroes shedding
And each drop is worth a thousand Portugales.

sp.speaker: bal.
sp.l: I will top thy head for that ambitious word.

sp.speaker: and.
sp.l: You cannot prince, see a revengeful sword
Waves over my head.

sp.speaker: bal.
sp.l: Another over mine
Let them both meet in crimson tinctures shine.

body.stage: They fight, and andrea hath balthezer downe. Enter Portugales and releeue balthezer and kil andrea.

sp.speaker: and.
sp.l: O I am slain, help me Horatio,
My foes are base, and slay me cowardly,
Farewell dear, dearest Bellimperia,
Yet herein joy is mingled with sad death,
I keep her favour longer than my breath.

body.stage: Sound Alarum Andrea slain and Prince Balthezer vanting on him. Enter Ieronimo, Horatio and Lord Generall.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: My other soul, my bosom, my heart's friend,
My O Andrea slain, I will have the price
Of him in princely blood, Prince Balthezer
My sword shall strike true strains,
And etch Andreas ransom forth thy veins,
Lord General drive them hence while I make war?

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: Hath war made thee so impudent and young,
My sword shall give correction to thy tongue.

sp.speaker: Iero.
sp.l: Correct thy rascals Prince, thou correct him,
Lug with him boy, honours in blood best swim.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: So young and valorous this arm never met,
So strong a courage of so green a set.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: If thou beest valiant cease these idle words,
And let revenge hang on our glittering swords,
With this proud prince the haughty Balthezer.

body.stage: Horatio has prince Balthezer downe, then Enter lorenze and seizes his weapons.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Hand of lorenzo touch not my prisoner.

sp.speaker: lo.
sp.l: He is my prisoner,
I seized his weapons first.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: O base renown it is easy to seize those,
Were forced laid down.

sp.speaker: lor.
sp.l: My lance first threw him from his

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.l: Thy Lance lorenzo ? now by my beard you lie?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Well my Lord to you a while I tender my
Whole prisoner.

sp.speaker: lor.
sp.l: Horatio, you tender me part of mine own you know.

sp.speaker: ho.
sp.l: Well peace, with my blood dispense
Until my liege shall end the difference.

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.l: lorenzo, thou dost boast of base renown,
Why I could whip all these, were their hose down.

sp.speaker: ho.
sp.l: Speak prince to whether dost thou yield?

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: The vanquished yields to both, to you first

sp.speaker: ho.
sp.l: O abject prince, what dost thou yield to two?

sp.speaker: Ier:
sp.l: Content thee boy, thou shalt sustain no wrong,
I will to the king before, and let him know,
The sum of victory, and his overthrow.

sp.speaker: lor.
sp.l: Andrea slain, thanks to the stars above,
I will choose my Sister out her second love.

sp.speaker: ho.
sp.l: Come noble rib of honour, valiant carcass,
I loved thee so entirely when thou breathest,
That I could die were it but to bleed with thee,
And wish me wounds, even for society.
Heaven and this arm, once saved thee from thy foe,
When his all wrathful sword did basely point
At the rich circle of thy labouring heart,
Thou grovelling under indignation,
Of sword and ruth, O then stepped heaven and I,
Between the stroke, but now alack must die:
Since so the powers above have writ it down,
In marble leaves that death is mortal crowned,
Come then my friend in purple I will bear,
Thee to my private tent, and then prepare,
For honoured Funeral for thy melting course.
sp.stage: He takes his scarfeand ties it about his arme.
sp.l: This scarf I will wear in memory of our souls,
And of our mutual loves, here, here, I will wind it,
And full as often as I think on thee,
I will kiss this little ensign, this soft banner,
Smeared with foes blood, all for the master's honour,
Alas I pity Bellimperias eyes,
Just at this instant her heart sinks and dies.

body.stage: Exit Horatio carying andrea on his back.

sp.speaker: Iero.
sp.l: My boy ads treble comfort to my age,
His share is greatest in this victory,
The Portugales are slain and put to flight,
By Spaniards force, most by Horatioes might:
I will to the Spanish tents to see my son,
Give him my blessing, and then all is done.

body.stage: Enter two, dragging of ensignes, then the funerall of Andrea: next Horatio, and Lorenzo, leading prince Balthezer captiue, then the Lord General with others mourning, a great cry within. Caron, a boat, a boat, then Enter charon, and the ghoast of Andrea.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: O my Lords?
See Don Andreas ghost salutes me, see embraces me.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: It is your love that shapes this apprehension.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Do you not see him plainly Lords,
Now he would kiss my cheek, O my pale friend,
Wert thou anything but a ghost I could love thee,
See he points at his own hearse, mark all,
As if he did rejoice at funeral.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: Revenge give my tongue freedom, to paint her part,
To thank Horatio, and commend his heart.

sp.speaker: Reueng.
sp.l: No you will blab secrets then?

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: By Charons boat I will not.

sp.speaker: Reueng.
sp.l: Nay you shall not: therefore pass,
Secrets in hell are locked with doors of brass:
Use action if you will, but not in voice,
Your friend conceives in signs how you rejoice.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: See, see, he points to have his go forward on&H5;,
I prithee rest, it shall be done sweet Don,
O now he is vanished.

body.stage: Sound trumpets and a peale of ordenance.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: I am a happy Ghost,
Revenge, my passage now cannot be crossed,
Come charon: come hells Sculler, waft me over,
You sable streams which look like molten pitch,
My Funeral rights are made, my hearse hung rich.

body.stage: Exit Ghost and Reueng a great noise within.

sp.l: Charon: a boat, Charon, charon?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Who calls so loud on charon.
Indeed it is such a time the truth to tell,
I never want a fare, to pass to hell.

body.stage: Sound a florish Enter marching Horatio and Lorenzo, Leading prince Balthezer, Lord Generall, Phillippo, and Cassimero, with followers.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: These honoured rights and worthy duties spent
Upon the Funeral of Andreas dust,
Those once his valiant ashes, march we now
Homeward with victory to crown Spaines brow.

sp.speaker: Gene.
sp.l: The day is ours and joy yields happy treasure,
Set on to Spaine, in most triumphant measure.

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.l: Fore god I have just missed them: ha?
Soft Ieronimo: thou hast more friends
To take thy leave of: Look well about thee,
Embrace them, and take friendly leave,
My arms are of the shortest,
Let your loves piece them out,
You are welcome all, as I am a Gentleman,
For my sons sake, grant me a man at least,
At least I am: so good night kind gentles,
For I hope there is never a Jew among you all,
And so I leave you.
